text.tspan: Academic Stress in Indian High School Students During the COVID-19 Lockdown
In 2009, the Parliament of India passed the Right to Education Act (RTE), listing quality
education as a fundamental right for all children between the ages of 6-14. The Ministry of
Human Resource Development, Government of India, states that the purpose of the RTE Act is
to "ensure the all-round development of the child, building on the child's knowledge, potentiality
and talent and making the child free of fear, trauma and anxiety through a system of child-
friendly and child-centred learning" (Department of School Education & Literacy, 2019).
However, from this researcher's personal experience, and as reported in numerous research
studies, the Indian education system imposes a massive load of pressure and anxiety on students
due to various factors in its examination-oriented approach to learning (Deb et al., 2015; Kumar
& Talwar, 2014; Parikh et al., 2019; Verma et al., 2002).
The Indian education system is textbook-oriented and focuses on rote learning methods to
examine and evaluate students (Deb et al., 2015; Verma et al., 2002). The National Advisory
Committee (1993) stated that the style and content of the school textbooks and reference books
focus exclusively on the students' ability to reproduce facts and information to help students
excel in examinations. Furthermore, the vast syllabus included in these books forces teachers to
rush through the syllabus to complete the course in time, often disregarding the comprehension
level of students (Ramesh, 2017). Thus, education in India has become a means to prepare
students for exams rather than life itself. In fact, the Pratham Education Foundation (2018)
reported that 56% of 8th-grade students in India could not perform basic maths operations (e.g.,
dividing three-digit numbers by a one-digit number), while 27% of 8th-grade students could not
read.
